title: Ticket #7475: Add a Getting Started section to the manual
description:
Our manual lacks simple, clear instructions for how to get started with HTCondor. There are several different angles to consider: installing Condor, submitting your first job, setting up a basic Condor pool, possibly some basic management.

The most immediate need (and reason for this ticket) is a simple guide for setting up + administering a HTCondor pool. This will be focused towards smaller university campuses who are setting up new clusters and need basic, clear instructions. We want to provide a short, concise recipe that doesn't get bogged down by all the different options and flavors available.

Next, we'll add the existing Quick Start Guide (https://research.cs.wisc.edu/htcondor/manual/quickstart.html) directly into the manual.

We also eventually want an "Easy Install" page, describing how to set up a personal Condor with as few steps as possible. We already have a webpage with some basic install information (https://research.cs.wisc.edu/htcondor/instructions/) but even this gets too bogged down with options and details. This should be one page maximum.

Once we have enough content ready, we'll publish this all under a new top-level section called Getting Started.

2020-Jun-24 18:40:55 by tannenba:
CODE REVIEW ... actually, doc review! :P ....

The initial Quick Start instructions as they stand as of commit [59391] could still use some work.

First, more steps are required in the instructions than needed. We can reduce the number of steps and complexity. For instance, the first steps of installing from the repository requires wget to be installed (it is not installed in the Centos 7 basic image btw), leaves garbage files behind, requires answering questions. Why not instead just two commands: 

   $ sudo yum-config-manager --add-repo https://research.cs.wisc.edu/htcondor/yum/repo.d/htcondor-stable-rhel7.repo
   $ sudo yum install -y condor

Note the easy install above is dependent on the one-line change to our RPM repos specified in #7710.

Next, I think the suggested contents for security file config.d/50-security suffers from the following problems:

  1. unnecessary reverse DNS requirements
  2. no encryption, meaning private claim id information is being passed over the network in the clear
  3. host-based authorization for administrator commands (like condor_userprio)
  4. contains lines that are not needed like SEC_PASSWORD_FILE, which is already defined upon installation of the RPM
  5. is not completely cut-n-paste and yet it seems like it could be; for instance, references "condor-cm.mydomain.com".... could we replace this with $(CONDOR_HOST), since earlier in the instructions we tell people to define that?
  6. no comments in this config file... not a single one...

I suggest instead something like: 

config.d/50-security
# Require authentication, encryption, integrity
use SECURITY: Strong

# Set things up so authentication must happen  via the local filesystem
# or a pool password.  The local file system will be used to authenticate
# users submitting, removing, or editing jobs; this means we assume users will
# be logged into submit nodes.  HTCondor daemons themselves will only trust
# other daemons with the same pool password, a secret contained in file on each
# node that requires root access to read.
SEC_DEFAULT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS = FS, PASSWORD

# Allow READ level access (e.g. condor_status) with
# ANONYMOUS authentication, since we do not want users to have to login
# to the central manager just to see output from condor_status.
SEC_READ_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS = \
  $(SEC_DEFAULT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS), ANONYMOUS
SEC_CLIENT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS = \
 $(SEC_DEFAULT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS), ANONYMOUS

# This is the file that will contain the secret; it should only
# be readable by user root and will be created when you run
# sudo condor_store_cred add -c -p <password>.
SEC_PASSWORD_FILE = /etc/condor/passwords.d/POOL

ALLOW_DAEMON = condor_pool@*/*, condor@*/$(IP_ADDRESS)
ALLOW_NEGOTIATOR = condor_pool@*/$(CONDOR_HOST)
# Allow admin command like condor_user_prio from user root on any machine in the pool
ALLOW_ADMINISTRATOR = condor_pool@*/*

Also, instructions should say something about the permissions on the 50-security file (chmod 644).

Finally, the above pool password config could be in the examples directory so that these Quick Start instructions could just state to copy it into config.d. Even better, why not a "condor_quick_pool_setup" script that just takes three command-line arguments (one or more role arguments, address of central manager, pool password) and does everything this page says to do?

2020-Jun-26 13:21:22 by johnkn:
Should never config SEC_PASSWORD_FILE, this is in the param table, and in any case, if you want a different directory the knob to change would be SEC_PASSWORD_DIRECTORY not SEC_PASSWORD_FILE. 

from the param table
[SEC_PASSWORD_FILE]
default=$(SEC_PASSWORD_DIRECTORY)/POOL
type=string
tags=store_cred

[SEC_PASSWORD_DIRECTORY]
default=/etc/condor/passwords.d
win32_default=
type=path
tags=store_cred

2020-Jun-26 13:42:54 by zmiller:
I might suggest setting SEC_CLIENT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS to all methods. The server will filter out anything it doesn't like.

The reason for this is if someone wanted to submit to a remote pool, for example, and that pool was set up with SSL, FSREMOTE, IDTOKENS, KERBEROS, GSI, etc. If the user has a credential to be used with a remote pool, we shouldn't also force them to set an environment variable just to allow them to use it.

Same if a SchedD was going to flock to another pool using an SSL cert specifically installed by the admin. (Although this scenario probably has other config necessary so really the user/remote-submit example is the primary motivator.)

In general, because the server enforces the list and the order, the client should support as many things as it can for ease of use.

2020-Jul-01 14:55:57 by zmiller:
After discussion with Todd, we are going to keep this config as compact as possible. It's only meant to work with the stable series (8.8) and only with Linux. (hence no NTSSPI... the quickstart directions tell you to "yum install" anyways, so I think this is a fair assumption).

This differs slightly from the above config by adding "condor@*" to the ALLOW lists since that's what FS will map to, and then putting them in the same order as the authentication methods. (The latter makes no functional difference but reads a little nicer in my opinion)

Also not removing the explicit definition of SEC_PASSWORD_FILE because there is no entry in the stable series param table for that, or for SEC_PASSWORD_DIRECTORY either. 

config.d/50-security
# Require authentication, encryption, integrity
use SECURITY: Strong

# Set things up so authentication must happen  via the local filesystem
# or a pool password.  The local file system will be used to authenticate
# users submitting, removing, or editing jobs; this means we assume users will
# be logged into submit nodes.  HTCondor daemons themselves will only trust
# other daemons with the same pool password, a secret contained in file on each
# node that requires root access to read.
SEC_DEFAULT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS = FS, PASSWORD

# Allow READ level access (e.g. condor_status) with
# ANONYMOUS authentication, since we do not want users to have to login
# to the central manager just to see output from condor_status.
SEC_READ_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS = \
  $(SEC_DEFAULT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS), ANONYMOUS
SEC_CLIENT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS = \
 $(SEC_DEFAULT_AUTHENTICATION_METHODS), ANONYMOUS

# This is the file that will contain the secret; it should only
# be readable by user root and will be created when you run:
#
#     sudo condor_store_cred add -c -p <password>
#
SEC_PASSWORD_FILE = /etc/condor/passwords.d/POOL

# Allow principals that authenticated using FS (condor) or PASSWORD (condor_pool)
ALLOW_DAEMON = condor@*/*, condor_pool@*/*
ALLOW_NEGOTIATOR = condor@*/$(CONDOR_HOST), condor_pool@*/$(CONDOR_HOST)
# Allow admin command like condor_user_prio from any machine in the pool
ALLOW_ADMINISTRATOR = condor@*/*, condor_pool@*/*

I was able to get this configuration working, with one catch: in my VM testbed the negotiator was unable to match jobs because of an ipv4 vs. ipv6 mismatch. I fixed it by disabling ipv6. 2020-Jul-27 12:23:15 by karpel:
Just gave this a read since it was linked on a Nikhef email. Thoughts:

  • I'd really like to see some more "conversational" text in this guide, describing what's going on instead of just puking out things to copy-paste. Each code block should have at least one sentence describing "what and why" for that block. This guide needs to teach just enough that they know where to go next, and right now I don't think it has that.
  • I'd prefer we don't echo text into files. Instead, do something like "add this line <example> to <this file>. The current way obscures the fact that you're building up a configuration file, which is necessary context. No need to name a specific editor; I think we can safely assume people reading this know how to edit text files.
  • I think it would be useful to push all the way through to running a sleep job as a smoke test.
  • We should consider having an "alternate track" for what to do if you want all of this on the same host (probably some .. note:: blocks placed throughout). Keep the three-machine setup as the "default" path.
  • This page should be prominently linked from the front page of the docs. It should be obvious where to go to learn how to set up a basic pool.
  • I think it needs to be explicitly stated that the hostnames of the three machines are placeholders. Yes, it's obvious to us, but not necessarily to random people on the internet.
